author: Potter
text: Pussy-cat sits by the fire--how should she be fair?

author: Potter
text: In walks the little dog--says "Pussy are you there?

author: Potter
text: How do you do Mistress Pussy?

author: Potter
text: Mistress Pussy, how do you do?"

author: Potter
text: "I thank you kindly, little dog, I fare as well as you!" [Old Rhyme]

author: Potter
text: Once upon a time there was a Pussy-cat called Ribby, who invited a little dog called Duchess to tea.

author: Potter
text: "Come in good time, my dear Duchess," said Ribby's letter, "and we will have something so very nice.

author: Potter
text: I am baking it in a pie-dish--a pie-dish with a pink rim.

author: Potter
text: You never tasted anything so good!

author: Potter
text: And YOU shall eat it all! _I_ will eat muffins, my dear Duchess!" wrote Ribby.

author: Potter
text: "I will come very punctually, my dear Ribby," wrote Duchess; and then at the end she added--"I hope it isn't mouse?"

author: Potter
text: And then she thought that did not look quite polite; so she scratched out "isn't mouse" and changed it to "I hope it will be fine," and she gave her letter to the postman.

author: Potter
text: But she thought a great deal about Ribby's pie, and she read Ribby's letter over and over again.

author: Potter
text: "I am dreadfully afraid it WILL be mouse!" said Duchess to herself--"I really couldn't, COULDN'T eat mouse pie.

author: Potter
text: And I shall have to eat it, because it is a party.

author: Potter
text: And MY pie was going to be veal and ham.

author: Potter
text: A pink and white pie-dish! and so is mine; just like Ribby's dishes; they were both bought at Tabitha Twitchit's."

author: Potter
text: Duchess went into her larder and took the pie off a shelf and looked at it.

author: Potter
text: "Oh what a good idea!

author: Potter
text: Why shouldn't I rush along and put my pie into Ribby's oven when Ribby isn't there?"

author: Potter
text: Ribby in the meantime had received Duchess's answer, and as soon as she was sure that the little dog would come--she popped HER pie into the oven.

author: Potter
text: There were two ovens, one above the other; some other knobs and handles were only ornamental and not intended to open.

author: Potter
text: Ribby put the pie into the lower oven; the door was very stiff.

author: Potter
text: "The top oven bakes too quickly," said Ribby to herself.

author: Potter
text: Ribby put on some coal and swept up the hearth.

author: Potter
text: Then she went out with a can to the well, for water to fill up the kettle.

author: Potter
text: Then she began to set the room in order, for it was the sitting-room as well as the kitchen.

author: Potter
text: When Ribby had laid the table she went out down the field to the farm, to fetch milk and butter.

author: Potter
text: When she came back, she peeped into the bottom oven; the pie looked very comfortable.

author: Potter
text: Ribby put on her shawl and bonnet and went out again with a basket, to the village shop to buy a packet of tea, a pound of lump sugar, and a pot of marmalade.

author: Potter
text: And just at the same time, Duchess came out of HER house, at the other end of the village.

author: Potter
text: Ribby met Duchess half-way down the street, also carrying a basket, covered with a cloth.

author: Potter
text: They only bowed to one another; they did not speak, because they were going to have a party.

author: Potter
text: As soon as Duchess had got round the corner out of sight--she simply ran!

author: Potter
text: Straight away to Ribby's house!

author: Potter
text: Ribby went into the shop and bought what she required, and came out, after a pleasant gossip with Cousin Tabitha Twitchit.

author: Potter
text: Ribby went on to Timothy Baker's and bought the muffins.

author: Potter
text: Then she went home.

author: Potter
text: There seemed to be a sort of scuffling noise in the back passage, as she was coming in at the front door.

author: Potter
text: But there was nobody there.

author: Potter
text: Duchess in the meantime, had slipped out at the back door.

author: Potter
text: "It is a very odd thing that Ribby's pie was NOT in the oven when I put mine in!

author: Potter
text: And I can't find it anywhere; I have looked all over the house.

author: Potter
text: I put MY pie into a nice hot oven at the top.

author: Potter
text: I could not turn any of the other handles; I think that they are all shams," said Duchess, "but I wish I could have removed the pie made of mouse!

author: Potter
text: I cannot think what she has done with it?

author: Potter
text: I heard Ribby coming and I had to run out by the back door!"

author: Potter
text: Duchess went home and brushed her beautiful black coat; and then she picked a bunch of flowers in her garden as a present for Ribby; and passed the time until the clock struck four.

author: Potter
text: Ribby--having assured herself by careful search that there was really no one hiding in the cupboard or in the larder--went upstairs to change her dress.

author: Potter
text: She came downstairs again, and made the tea, and put the teapot on the hob.

author: Potter
text: She peeped again into the BOTTOM oven, the pie had become a lovely brown, and it was steaming hot.

author: Potter
text: She sat down before the fire to wait for the little dog.

author: Potter
text: "I am glad I used the BOTTOM oven," said Ribby, "the top one would certainly have been very much too hot."

author: Potter
text: Very punctually at four o'clock, Duchess started to go to the party.

author: Potter
text: At a quarter past four to the minute, there came a most genteel little tap-tappity.

author: Potter
text: "Is Mrs. Ribston at home?" inquired Duchess in the porch.

author: Potter
text: "Come in! and how do you do, my dear Duchess?" cried Ribby.

author: Potter
text: "I hope I see you well?"

author: Potter
text: "Quite well, I thank you, and how do YOU do, my dear Ribby?" said Duchess.

author: Potter
text: "I've brought you some flowers; what a delicious smell of pie!"

author: Potter
text: "Oh, what lovely flowers!

author: Potter
text: Yes, it is mouse and bacon!"

author: Potter
text: "I think it wants another five minutes," said Ribby.

author: Potter
text: "Just a shade longer; I will pour out the tea, while we wait.

author: Potter
text: Do you take sugar, my dear Duchess?"

author: Potter
text: "Oh yes, please! my dear Ribby; and may I have a lump upon my nose?"

author: Potter
text: "With pleasure, my dear Duchess."

author: Potter
text: Duchess sat up with the sugar on her nose and sniffed--

author: Potter
text: "How good that pie smells!

author: Potter
text: I do love veal and ham--I mean to say mouse and bacon--"

author: Potter
text: She dropped the sugar in confusion, and had to go hunting under the tea- table, so did not see which oven Ribby opened in order to get out the pie.

author: Potter
text: Ribby set the pie upon the table; there was a very savoury smell.

author: Potter
text: Duchess came out from under the table-cloth munching sugar, and sat up on a chair.

author: Potter
text: "I will first cut the pie for you; I am going to have muffin and marmalade," said Ribby.

author: Potter
text: "I think"--(thought Duchess to herself)--"I THINK it would be wiser if I helped myself to pie; though Ribby did not seem to notice anything when she was cutting it.

author: Potter
text: What very small fine pieces it has cooked into!

author: Potter
text: I did not remember that I had minced it up so fine; I suppose this is a quicker oven than my own."

author: Potter
text: The pie-dish was emptying rapidly!

author: Potter
text: Duchess had had four helps already, and was fumbling with the spoon.

author: Potter
text: "A little more bacon, my dear Duchess?" said Ribby.

author: Potter
text: "Thank you, my dear Ribby; I was only feeling for the patty-pan."

author: Potter
text: "The patty-pan? my dear Duchess?"

author: Potter
text: "The patty pan that held up the pie-crust," said Duchess, blushing under her black coat.

author: Potter
text: "Oh, I didn't put one in, my dear Duchess," said Ribby; "I don't think that it is necessary in pies made of mouse."

author: Potter
text: Duchess fumbled with the spoon-- "I can't find it!" she said anxiously.

author: Potter
text: "There isn't a patty-pan," said Ribby, looking perplexed.

author: Potter
text: "Yes, indeed, my dear Ribby; where can it have gone to?" said Duchess.

author: Potter
text: Duchess looked very much alarmed, and continued to scoop the inside of the pie-dish.

author: Potter
text: "I have only four patty-pans, and they are all in the cupboard."

author: Potter
text: Duchess set up a howl.

author: Potter
text: "I shall die!

author: Potter
text: I shall die!

author: Potter
text: I have swallowed a patty-pan!

author: Potter
text: Oh, my dear Ribby, I do feel so ill!"

author: Potter
text: "It is impossible, my dear Duchess; there was not a patty-pan."

author: Potter
text: "Yes there WAS, my dear Ribby, I am sure I have swallowed it!"

author: Potter
text: "Let me prop you up with a pillow, my dear Duchess; where do you think you feel it?"

author: Potter
text: "Oh I do feel so ill ALL OVER me, my dear Ribby."

author: Potter
text: "Shall I run for the doctor?"

author: Potter
text: "Oh yes, yes! fetch Dr. Maggotty, my dear Ribby: he is a Pie himself, he will certainly understand."

author: Potter
text: Ribby settled Duchess in an armchair before the fire, and went out and hurried to the village to look for the doctor.

author: Potter
text: She found him at the smithy.

author: Potter
text: Ribby explained that her guest had swallowed a patty-pan.

author: Potter
text: Dr. Maggotty hopped so fast that Ribby had to run.

author: Potter
text: It was most conspicuous.

author: Potter
text: All the village could see that Ribby was fetching the doctor.

author: Potter
text: But while Ribby had been hunting for the doctor--a curious thing had happened to Duchess, who had been left by herself, sitting before the fire, sighing and groaning and feeling very unhappy.

author: Potter
text: "How COULD I have swallowed it! such a large thing as a patty-pan!"

author: Potter
text: She sat down again, and stared mournfully at the grate.

author: Potter
text: The fire crackled and danced, and something sizz-z-zled!

author: Potter
text: Duchess started!

author: Potter
text: She opened the door of the TOP oven;--out came a rich steamy flavour of veal and ham, and there stood a fine brown pie,-- and through a hole in the top of the pie-crust there was a glimpse of a little tin patty-pan!

author: Potter
text: Duchess drew a long breath--

author: Potter
text: "Then I must have been eating MOUSE!

author: Potter
text: No wonder I feel ill.

author: Potter
text: But perhaps I should feel worse if I had really swallowed a patty-pan!"

author: Potter
text: Duchess reflected--"What a very awkward thing to have to explain to Ribby!

author: Potter
text: I think I will put MY pie in the back-yard and say nothing about it.

author: Potter
text: When I go home, I will run round and take it away."

author: Potter
text: She put it outside the back-door, and sat down again by the fire, and shut her eyes; when Ribby arrived with the doctor, she seemed fast asleep.

author: Potter
text: "I am feeling very much better," said Duchess, waking up with a jump.

author: Potter
text: "I am truly glad to hear it!

author: Potter
text: He has brought you a pill, my dear Duchess!"

author: Potter
text: "I think I should feel QUITE well if he only felt my pulse," said Duchess, backing away from the magpie, who sidled up with something in his beak.

author: Potter
text: "It is only a bread pill, you had much better take it; drink a little milk, my dear Duchess!"

author: Potter
text: "I am feeling very much better, my dear Ribby," said Duchess.

author: Potter
text: "Do you not think that I had better go home before it gets dark?"

author: Potter
text: "Perhaps it might be wise, my dear Duchess."

author: Potter
text: Ribby and Duchess said good-bye affectionately, and Duchess started home.

author: Potter
text: Half-way up the lane she stopped and looked back; Ribby had gone in and shut her door.

author: Potter
text: Duchess slipped through the fence, and ran round to the back of Ribby's house, and peeped into the yard.

author: Potter
text: Upon the roof of the pig-stye sat Dr. Maggotty and three jackdaws.

author: Potter
text: The jackdaws were eating piecrust, and the magpie was drinking gravy out of a patty-pan.

author: Potter
text: Duchess ran home feeling uncommonly silly!

author: Potter
text: When Ribby came out for a pailful of water to wash up the tea-things, she found a pink and white pie-dish lying smashed in the middle of the yard.

author: Potter
text: Ribby stared with amazement-- "Did you ever see the like! so there really WAS a patty-pan?

author: Potter
text: But MY patty-pans are all in the kitchen cupboard.

author: Potter
text: Well I never did!

author: Potter
text: Next time I want to give a party--I will invite Cousin Tabitha Twitchit!"
